metadata.case_name: Sri-la-Sri Subramania Desika Gnana Sambanda Pandarasannadhi v. State of Madras

facts.text: Sri Thyagarajaswami Temple at Tiruvarur has specific endowments called Kattalais, including Rajan Kattalai, managed by hereditary trustees; trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai vests in head of Dharmapuram Mutt.
In 1910, suit under s.92 CPC filed for scheme to manage temple affairs; scheme settled by Sub-Court Thanjavur and confirmed by High Court in Gnana Sambanda v. Vaithilinga Mudaliar.
In Ramanathan Chettiar v. Balayee Ammal, High Court held Kattalais are appendages of temple, no private ownership by trustees.
In 1931, suit under s.92 CPC for modification of scheme; modifications made by District Court, East Thanjavur.
Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 (Madras Act II of 1927) passed; amended by Act IX of 1937 adding Chapter VI-A for notification of mismanaged temples/endowments.
On May 25, 1937, notification issued under s.65A(5)(b) of 1927 Act declaring temple and Kattalais subject to Chapter VI-A.
Executive Officer appointed on July 12, 1937; powers defined on July 30, 1937, taking charge of temple and Kattalais.

Suit No. 20 of 1938 filed by Pandarasannadhi in Madras High Court challenging 1937 notification; compromise decree on August 1, 1940 maintaining notification but restoring possession to trustee with safeguards and Board's supervision.

Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 (Act XIX of 1951) came into force on September 30, 1951, repealing 1927 Act; s.103(c) deems prior notifications under s.64 for 5 years from commencement.
On August 4, 1956, Governor of Madras issued notification under s.64(4) of 1951 Act continuing 1937 notification for 5 years from September 30, 1956.
Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 295 of 1958 in Madras High Court challenging 1956 notification; dismissed on August 11, 1961.
Madras Act IX of 1956 amended s.64(4) to allow continuation for further periods not exceeding 5 years.
Madras Act XXII of 1959 came into force January 1, 1960; s.72(7) validates prior notifications under 1951 Act as under new Act; further amended by Act XL of 1961 retrospectively.

legal_issues.text: Whether notification under s.64(4) of Madras Act XIX of 1951 extending prior notification requires compliance with principles of natural justice, including opportunity to be heard.
Whether proceedings under s.64(4) are quasi-judicial, akin to those under s.64(3).

petitioner_arguments.text: Trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai is hereditary right of property under Art.19(1)(f); s.64 empowers arbitrary deprivation, unconstitutional.
Notification issued without opportunity to show cause why earlier notification should not be extended, violating natural justice.

respondent_arguments.text: Order under s.64(4) to cancel or continue notification is purely administrative, not quasi-judicial; no need for hearing as material from initial enquiry under s.64(2) suffices.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.64(4) of Act XIX of 1951; Shri Radeshyam Khare v. State of MP

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings under s.64(4) are quasi-judicial like s.64(3); Government must consider if continuation needed in interests of administration, requiring hearing for trustee to show cause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nature and effect of order under s.64(4) similar to s.64(3); natural justice obligatory.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred: plea of no hearing was raised in rejoinder affidavit; impugned notification does not expire on Sept 30, 1961 due to Madras Act XXII of 1959.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court's reasons for refusing writ invalid.

holdings.text: Notification under s.64(4) invalid without opportunity to trustee; must quash to allow showing cause against extension.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vythilinga Pandara Sannadhi v. Somasundara Mudaliar
precedents_cited.relevance: Treated Kattalais attached to temple as different category.
Kattalais are appendages of temple, no private ownership.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Radeshyam Khare v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished sections with different nature; not applicable to equate s.64(4) with administrative acts.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 (Madras Act XIX of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs notification, continuation of notified temples/endowments; requires natural justice for quasi-judicial orders.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 (Madras Act II of 1927)
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior law for notifying mismanaged endowments; deemed continued under 1951 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Act IX of 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Allowed continuation of notifications for further periods.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Used for suits framing/modifying schemes for temple management.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner's claim of trusteeship as property right; not decided by SC.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; directed issue of writ quashing notification dated August 4, 1956 issued under s.64(4) of Act XIX of 1951.

key_quotes.text: It is difficult to understand how Government can legitimately and reasonably decide to extend the notification, unless it gives an opportunity to the Trustee to show cause why it should not be continued.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on natural justice requirement under s.64(4).

key_quotes.text: The nature of the order which can be passed under s.64(4) and its effect on the rights of the trustee are exactly similar to the order which can be passed under s.64(3).
key_quotes.speaker: court
